awd_titl_txt: How Do Volcanoes Work: Reconciling the Cold and Warm Storage Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Volcanic eruptions are some of the most destructive natural hazards on Earth, costing the lives of hundreds of people and destroying many infrastructures all over the world. The question of identifying the processes occurring beneath volcanoes is of crucial significance, as such knowledge is necessary to better predict destructive eruptions. An important aspect of petrology and geochemistry is to develop new tools that allow researchers to assess how volcanic magma chambers work and evolve. Unfortunately, applications of these tools give contrasting answers that lead to contradictory models in the literature for the storage and eruption capacity of volcanic reservoirs. This project seeks to reconcile the community by providing a common ground where proponents of different models and tools can meet and learn, Only an open-minded, reconciled approach would allow the identification of trends among different volcanoes and improve our understanding of volcanic systems that pose a threat to human life and infrastructure. This project broadens the participation of underrepresented groups, and supports a graduate student.

In the past couple of years, two models have emerged for the evolution of silicic magma systems: Cold Storage, based on geospeedometry applications, and Warm Storage, mostly based on thermal models and zircon geochronology/geochemistry studies. Both models have critical implications on the mechanisms of volcanic eruptions, and are highly debated within the petrology community. A lot of efforts are currently allotted in the literature to discuss the merits of the various tools used in both cold and warm storage models; however, none of those tools have been applied together on the same volcanic systems. Therefore, it is unclear if the different storage conditions documented so far in the literature are linked to the analytical methods used, or reflect a more fundamental problem, that physical mechanisms in volcanic systems are too variable for the establishment of a unified model. In this project, we propose to apply analytical methods used in the past to bolster the arguments for both cold and warm storage together on the same volcanic systems and address the most fundamental question, do all volcanoes of similar size and tectonic context work the similarly. We propose to apply Sr diffusion in plagioclase (cold storage tool) together with zircon geochronology/geochemistry (warm storage tool) on three different arc volcanoes that were previously used to bolster either the cold or warm storage argument, the St. Lucia Soufriere Volcanic Center, Mt. Hood (Cascade Mountain Range) and the Okataina Caldera (Taupo Volcanic Arc, New Zealand). Our work will concentrate on both lavas and cogenetic plutonic enclaves from the three case studies. By combining results from all set of tools, samples and eruptive events, we will draw a more comprehensive thermal history for these three volcanoes, identify common features in volcanic reservoirs of similar size and setting and test the cold and warm storage tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Title: Investigating Volcanic Storage Models Using Advanced Geochemical Tools

Overview: Our NSF-funded project aimed to deepen our understanding of the thermal histories and magma storage conditions beneath arc volcanoes. We concentrated our efforts on Mt. Hood, a prominent volcano in the Cascade Mountain Range, to test and reconcile theories of cold and warm magma storage. Using cutting-edge techniques like Sr and Mg-in-plagioclase diffusion geospeedometry and Ti-in-zircon thermometry, we sought to create a comprehensive thermal history of Mt. Hood’s volcanic system, enhancing our ability to predict volcanic behavior.

Intellectual Merit: Through this project, we made significant strides in understanding magma storage at Mt. Hood. One major accomplishment was the development of a novel error evaluation approach for diffusion models. This approach addressed critical gaps in previous research, ensuring more accurate and reliable results. We also enhanced analytical procedures for Sr analyses and incorporated Ti-in-zircon thermometry into diffusion models. Our work included the detailed analysis of 102 plagioclase crystals for Sr and Mg diffusion, providing invaluable data on the thermal state of the volcano’s magmatic system.

Our research revealed a heterogeneous mush beneath Mt. Hood, with regions that have survived above the solidus (the temperature at which rocks start to melt) for over 30,000 years. This indicates a complex interplay between cold and warm storage conditions, challenging the previously held belief in a single, cold storage regime. The results showed that some parts of the magmatic system remained hot for extended periods, while others incorporated colder, solid materials during magma mobilization just before eruptions.

Additionally, our full error determination using Monte Carlo simulations underscored the necessity of selecting optimal grains for reliable results. This thorough analysis highlighted the significant uncertainties in diffusion modeling that had been previously underestimated, emphasizing the importance of comprehensive error assessment.

Incorporating Ti-in-zircon thermometry further validated our findings. This technique provided temperature constraints for the diffusion model, showing average melt temperatures of 784±10°C. By integrating plagioclase diffusion timescales with zircon temperatures, we gained a more nuanced understanding of magma storage conditions at Mt. Hood, revealing maximum post-recharge residence durations up to 112,000 years at 700°C.

Broader Impacts: Our project has significant implications for the broader understanding of volcanic behavior, which is crucial for assessing volcanic hazards and risks. By sharing our findings through public lectures, workshops, and publications, we aim to enhance public awareness and preparedness for volcanic events. This outreach helps communities understand the complexities of volcanic systems and the potential risks they pose.

One of the critical insights from our research is that arc volcanoes, such as Mt. St. Helens and Mt. Rainier, may be more dangerous and harder to predict than previously thought. If a volcano follows a cold storage model, any signs of liquid magma activity beneath it suggest an imminent eruption. However, if magma presence is a normal state in dormant volcanoes, then these early warning signs are not present, complicating the prediction of eruptions and potentially increasing the risk to nearby populations.

The project also provided valuable training opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. These young scientists gained hands-on experience with advanced geochemical techniques and data analysis, fostering the next generation of volcanologists. This training is essential for their professional development and future contributions to the field.

Moreover, the technological and methodological advancements from our project have broader applications in geological studies. The refined geochemical tools and error evaluation approaches we developed can be applied to various geological settings, improving our overall capability to interpret and predict geological phenomena.

Conclusion: This project has significantly advanced our understanding of magma storage conditions beneath Mt. Hood. By developing and applying refined geochemical tools, we have provided a more detailed picture of the volcano’s thermal history. Our findings challenge previous assumptions about magma storage and underscore the importance of integrating multiple methods for reliable results. These insights contribute to the broader goal of improving volcanic hazard assessment and preparedness, ultimately helping to protect communities living near active volcanoes such as Mt. St. Helens and Mt. Rainier.
